DT Article
TI Geoemydid turtles from the Late Eocene Maoming basin, southern China.
AU Claude, Julien
   Zhang, Jiang-Yong
   Li, Tian-Jun
   Mo, Jin-You
   Kuang, Xue-Wen
   Tong, Haiyan
SO Bulletin de la Societe Geologique de France
VL 183
IS 6
PS 641-651
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The fossil record of testudinoid turtles of China during the
   Eocene-Oligocene is poorly documented. The Maoming basin is one of the
   few Paleogene basin in southern China having yielded a rich turtle fauna
   including Trionychidae, Carettochelyidae and Geoemydidae
   (Testudinoidea). Testudinoids were known in this basin by a single,
   supposed aquatic species, Isometremys lacuna CHOW and YEH, 1962. The
   examination of the new material collected since the first description,
   and a reexamination of the type material provide additional data on the
   morphology of that species. In addition, a second geoemydid,
   Guangdongemys pingi nov gen. nov sp., is described on the basis of shell
   material. Both species are supposed to be aquatic, and have a probably
   basal position in the geoemydid phylogeny.

DT Article
TI A news [new] genus, Ragesaurus (Squamata, Anguidae, Anguinae) from the
   lower Pleistocene of the islas Medas (Catalonia, Spain).
FT Un nouveau genre, Ragesaurus (Squamata, Anguidae, Anguinae), du
   Pleistocene inferieur des lies Medas (Catalogne, Espagne).
AU Bailon, Salvador (salvador.bailon@mnhn.fr) 
   Auge, Marc
SO Bulletin de la Societe Geologique de France
VL 183
IS 6
PS 683-688
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 2
AB Here we describe the dentary of a small anguine lizard, Ragesaurus n.
   gen., from the early Pleistocene of the Medas islands (Spain).
   Ragesaurus shares several morphological characters with the Anguini, but
   the new species differs from other extant and fossil Anguinae in: the
   special morphology of the antero-inferior alveolar foramen, closed by a
   septum; the narrowing of the Meckelian groove in the middle part of the
   specimen, where the dorsal and ventral margins of the Meckelian groove
   come close to one another and, to a lesser extent, the tooth morphology.

PT J
AN ZOOR14909036530
DT Article
TI A jawed polychaete fauna from the late Ludlow Kozlowskii event interval
   in the Prague Basin (Czech Republic).
AU Tonarova, Petra (petra.tonarova@geology.cz) 
   Eriksson, Mats E.
   Hints, Olle
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 87
IS 4
PS 713-732
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB This paper deals with a diverse fauna of polychaetes possessing jaws (=
   scolecodonts) from the late Silurian Kopanina Formation of the Prague
   Basin (Czech Republic). The most common genera are Kettnerites,
   Oenonites and Pistoprion; the entire collection contains at least 16
   genera. This is in stark contrast to the four genera recorded from this
   region by previous authors. The fauna described shows great similarities
   with coeval ones reported from the Baltic area (Gotland and Estonia),
   Siberia, Arctic Canada and the British Isles. These new data thus extend
   the palaeobiogeographical and palaeolatitudinal distribution of several
   taxa, particularly at the genus but also the species level. The sampled
   interval embraces the Kozlowskii event and its effects on the
   polychaetes are briefly discussed. Although the collections are
   relatively small, particularly from post-event strata, a faunal
   reorganisation is apparent. The studied collection enabled the
   stratigraphical ranges of some taxa, including tretoprionids and
   possibly polychaeturids, to be extended into the late Ludlow. One new
   species, "Mochtyella" pragensis, is described.
C1 Tonarova, Petra; Charles Univ, Fac Sci, Albertov 6, Prague, 12843 2,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM petra.tonarova@geology.cz
RI Hints, Olle/B-8236-2019
OI Hints, Olle/0000-0003-4670-4452; Tonarova, Petra/0000-0001-5002-6389
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1214-1119
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR14909038930
DT Article
TI First Viridotheres Manning, 1996, from Japan, with a key to the species
   (Decapoda, Brachyura, Pinnotheridae).
AU Ahyong, Shane T. (Shane.Ahyong@austmus.gov.au) 
   Komai, Tomoyuki
   Watanabe, Tetsuya
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 35-47
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Viridotheres takedai sp. nov., the seventh species of the genus, is
   described from Japan. It is the fourth species known from the Indo-West
   Pacific and the first to be recorded from Japanese waters. Viridotheres
   takedai is also the first pinnotherid to be recorded from Nipponoclava
   gigantea (Sowerby), a tube dwelling bivalve. An unusual feature of adult
   male V. takedai is the well-developed exopod on gonopod 2, recognised
   here for the first time from a brachyuran as a normal feature (rather
   than the result of a developmental abnormality). The gonopod 2 exopod is
   absent in the juvenile male, so its presence in adult V. takedai may be
   derived feature. We also report the occurrence of well-developed gonopod
   2 exopods in male Nepinnotheres affinis (Burger, 1895), N. androgynus
   Manning, 1993, and the hexapodid Thaumastoplax anomalipes Miers, 1881.
   Most pinnotherid species are known at present only from females and when
   males of these species are discovered, the phenomenon may prove more
   widespread than currently known. A key to the species of Viridotheres
   Manning, 1996 is provided.
C1 Ahyong, Shane T.; Australian Museum, 6 College St., Sydney, NSW 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM Shane.Ahyong@austmus.gov.au
OI Ahyong, Shane/0000-0002-2820-4158
SC Zoology
SN 1570-7024
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Viridotheres [North Pacific / Japan / New record; systematics]. 
   Viridotheres takedai [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Viridotheres - Manning 1996 (Brachyura): [Key to species, Adult females,
   p. 45; New record]. 
   Viridotheres takedai (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 36].

PT J
AN ZOOR14909038931
DT Article
TI Thymops takedai, a new species of deepwater lobster from the Southwest
   Atlantic Ocean with additional records of 'thymopine' lobsters
   (Decapoda, Nephropidae).
AU Ahyong, Shane T. (Shane.Ahyong@austmus.gov.au) 
   Webber, W. Richard
   Chan, Tin-Yam
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 49-61
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of deep-water clawed lobster, Thymops takedai, is
   described from the Scotia Sea, near South Georgia, representing the
   second species of the genus. The new species differs from Thymops
   birsteini (Zarenkov & Semenov, 1972) in having a ventrally spinose or
   serrated rostrum (versus smooth or finely granular), a non-flagellate
   maxilliped 3 exopod (versus exopod with flagellum), and a longer
   branchiocardiac groove that reaches to the posterior quarter of the
   carapace (versus slightly beyond midlength). We also report additional
   specimens of T. birsteini and Thymopsis nilenta Holthuis, 1974, and
   document considerable variation in the condition of the exopods on
   maxillipeds 2 and 3 of Thymopsis. This variation in the maxillipedal
   exopods in Thymopsis overlaps with that of Thymops, rendering the two
   genera otherwise almost indistinguishable apart from subtle distinctions
   in carapace groove patterns. Thus, the taxonomic utility of recognising
   both genera as separate is questionable and further study may show that
   the two genera should be synonymised.
C1 Ahyong, Shane T.; Australian Museum, 6 College St., Sydney, NSW 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM Shane.Ahyong@austmus.gov.au
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1570-7024
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; General morphology;
   Appendages; Mouthparts; Evolution; Variation; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean
DE Thymops; Thymopsis [Maxillipeds / Maxillipedal exopods variation /
   Systematics] [Morphological variation /  / ]. 
   Thymops birsteini [South Atlantic / Falkland Islands / Recorded]. 
   Thymops takedai [South Atlantic / South Georgia / New species]. 
   Thymopsis nilenta [South Atlantic / South Georgia / Systematics;
   recorded]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Astacura
OR Thymops - Holthuis 1974 (Astacura): [Diagnostic characters, P. 59]. 
   Thymops birsteini (Astacura). 
   Thymops takedai (Astacura): [Sp nov, South Georgia (marine), P. 50]. 
   Thymopsis - Holthuis 1974 (Astacura): [Diagnostic characters, P. 59]. 
   Thymopsis nilenta - Holthuis 1974 (Astacura).

DT Article
TI Caprella takedai, a new species of caprellid amphipod from off Ito, the
   east coast of Izu Peninsula, Shizuoka, Japan.
AU Aoki, Masakazu (m-aoki@m.tohoku.ac.jp) 
   Ito, Atsushi
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 63-69
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Caprella takedai, a new caprellid amphipod is described from off Ito,
   east coast of the Izu Peninsula, Shizuoka, Japan. The species was found
   attached to green alga, Cladophora wrightiana Harvey, at a depth of 15
   m. Morphological characteristics of the species are very close to C.
   subinermis Mayer, but it is easy to identify the species from others by
   the presence of a distinctive triangular projection on the palmar
   process of gnathopod 2 propodus.

DT Article
TI Mithracites takedai, a new homoloid crab (Decapoda, Brachyura) from the
   Lower Cretaceous (Aptian) of Colombia.
AU Van Bakel, Barry W.M. (barryvanbakel@gmail.com) 
   Guinot, Daniele
   Jagt, John W.M.
   Fraaije, Rene H.B.
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 81-90
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new homoloid crab, Mithracites takedai, is described on the basis of
   two specimens from Colombia, preserved in a limestone nodule of early
   Aptian (Early Cretaceous) age, as dated by co-occurring ammonite
   species. The new species differs from the type species, M. vectensis, by
   a distinctly sulcate front, a narrower anterior mesogastric process, and
   a differently shaped cardiac region. The status of the family
   Mithracitidae Stevcic, 2005, is revised and an emended diagnosis is
   provided; the appearance of the linea homolica in extinct homoloids is
   discussed.
C1 Van Bakel, Barry W.M.; Oertijdmuseum De Groene poort, Bosscheweg 80,
   NL-5283 WB Boxtel, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM barryvanbakel@gmail.com

   supporting structures; Exoskeleton; Evolution; Variation; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   [Morphological variation /  / ].

DT Article
TI A new species of Anisomysis Hansen, 1910 (Mysida, Mysidae) from inshore
   waters of a small island in the Andaman Sea.
AU Hanamura, Yukio (hanamura@affrc.go.jp) 
   Tsutsui, Isao
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 127-136
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Anisomysis Hansen, 1910 (Mysida, Mysidae) collected
   from inshore waters of Racha Yai Island in the Andaman Sea, eastern
   Indian Ocean, is reported upon. The new species, Anisomysis
   (Paranisomysis) takedai, shows a close affinity to A. (P.) minicoyensis
   Biju et al., 2006. The new species can be distinguished from A. (P.)
   minicoyensis by having a short rostrum barely reaching the base of the
   antennular peduncle, a comparatively broader antennal scale, a
   proportionately longer second article of the male fourth pleopodal
   exopod, and a larger number of setae on the telson.
C1 Hanamura, Yukio; National Research Institute of Fisheries Science,
   Fuku-ura 2-12-4, Kanazawa-ku, Yokohama, Kanagawa 236-8648, Japan, Japan.

TI A new genus and new species of chasmocarcinid crab (Decapoda, Brachyura,
   Goneplacoidea) from shallow waters in Japan.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
   Ng, Peter K.
   Yamada, Yusuke
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 137-154
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and new species of chasmocarcinid crab, Microtopsis takedai,
   is described on the basis of four specimens from Okinawa, Ryukyu
   Islands, Japan. The new genus is characterized by the subtriangular
   merus of the third maxilliped, the presence of a row of closely set
   stiff setae on the cutting margin of the pollex of the minor male chela
   (for both chelae in the case of females), the relatively short male
   abdomen, and the stout male first gonopod with a distal part encircled
   by short to long spines.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba, 955-2,
   Aoba-cho, Chuo-ku, Chiba 260-8682, Japan, Japan.

TI Ebalia takedai, a new species of leucosiid crab (Decapoda, Brachyura)
   from Panglao, Philippines.
AU Komatsu, Hironori (h-komatu@kahaku.go.jp) 
   Manuel-Santos, Marivene R.
   Ng, Peter K.L.
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 155-162
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the family Leucosiidae, Ebalia takedai, is described
   and illustrated on the basis of four ovigerous females from Panglao,
   Philippines. Ebalia takedai n. sp. resembles E. longispinosa Ihle, 1918,
   E. sakaii Takeda & Miyake, 1972 and E. weberi Komatsu & Takeda, 2007, in
   the shape and armature of the carapace, mouth parts and cheliped, but
   can be distinguished from them by having two spines on the anterolateral
   margin of carapace.

TI Michelea takeda sp. nov. (Crustacea, Decapoda, Axiidea, Micheleidae)
   from the South China Sea.
AU Liu, Wenliang
   Liu, Ruiyu (J.Y. Liu) (jyliu@qdio.ac.cn) 
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 175-181
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Michelea Kensley & Heard, 1991, M. takeda,
   from the Beibu Gulf (Tonkin Gulf), northern South China Sea, is
   described and illustrated. The new species is closely allied to M. leura
   (Poore & Griffin, 1979) but differs markedly in its wider rostrum, the
   lower margin of the propodus of pereopod 1 being distinctly convex and
   the shorter uropodal endopod. This genus is recorded for the first time
   from Chinese waters.

TI A new genus and species of deep-water xanthid crab (Decapoda, Brachyura,
   Xanthidae) from the Philippines.
AU Mendoza, Jose C.E. (jcmendoza@nus.edu.sg) 
   Ng, Peter K.L.
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 197-210
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of deep-water xanthid crab is described from the
   Philippines. Takedax gabrielae gen. et sp. nov. resembles Medaeops
   Guinot, 1967, in the cristate anterior margins of the ambulatory meri.
   It is also similar to Monodaeus Guinot, 1967, in the long cheliped
   fingers, the shape of the ambulatory legs, and the form of the merus of
   the third maxilliped. Takedax gen. nov. is separated from both known
   genera by a suite of characters related to the carapace, epistome,
   pereiopods, male thoracic sternum, and male abdomen.

TI A new genus and species of Aphanodactylidae Ahyong & Ng, 2009 (Decapoda,
   Brachyura, Pinnotheroidea) from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan.
AU Naruse, Tohru (naruse@lab.u-ryukyu.ac.jp) 
   Maenosono, Tadafumi
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 225-231
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and new species of pinnotheroid crab of the family
   Aphanodactylidae, Takedactylus masatsunei, is described from Sesoko
   Island, adjacent to Okinawa Island, Ryukyu Islands, Japan. The new
   species differs markedly from known aphanodactylid genera by the
   characters of the carapace, epistome, third maxilliped and ambulatory
   legs, and as such, must be placed in its own new genus. This study
   brings the number of taxa in the family to nine species in five genera.

   University of the Ryukyus, 870 Uehara, Taketomi, Okinawa 907-1541,
   Japan, Japan.

PT J
AN ZOOR14909038998
DT Article
TI A new species of cnidarian-associated shrimp of the genus Cuapetes
   Clark, 1919 (Decapoda, Palaemonidae) from Suruga Bay, Japan.
AU Okuno, Junji (okuno@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 233-244
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of pontoniine shrimp, Cuapetes takedai sp. nov., is
   described and illustrated on the basis of five specimens from Suruga
   Bay, Honshu, Japan. The new species is closely related to C. nilandensis
   (Borradaile) on account of the lack of meral and ischial distoventral
   teeth on the second pereiopod and the presence of elongate distoventral
   spines on the propodi of the ambulatory pereiopods, but can be readily
   distinguished from the latter species by the lack of a supraorbital
   spine and the carpus of the second pereiopod being considerably longer
   than the palm. The new species is associated with the hydroid,
   Lytocarpia niger (Nutting) and an unidentified gorgonarian.
C1 Okuno, Junji; Coastal Branch of Natural History Museum and Institute,
   Chiba, 123 Yoshio, Katsuura, Chiba 299-5242, Japan, Japan.

DT Article
TI A new species of the hermit crab genus Diogenes Dana, 1851 (Decapoda,
   Anomura, Diogenidae) from Lombok, Indonesia.
AU Rahayu, Dwi Listyo (dwilistyo@yahoo.com) 
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 263-274
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new hermit crab species of the family Diogenidae, Diogenes takedai sp.
   nov., is described from sea grass beds of Lombok Island, Indonesia. The
   new species appears closest to D. tirmiziae Siddiqui & McLaughlin, 2003,
   in having banded ocular peduncles and pereopods and similar armatures of
   the antennal peduncle and left chela, but is distinguished from that
   species by the tapered ocular peduncles and moderately narrow corneas,
   and the propodi of the second and third pereopods without spines on the
   dorsal margin. The new species is compared to other similar congenerics
   from Indo-West Pacific. The species of Diogenes known from Indonesian
   waters are briefly reviewed.
C1 Rahayu, Dwi Listyo; Marine Bio-Industry Technical Implementation Unit,
   Research Center for Oceanography, Indonesian Institute of Sciences
   (LIPI), Teluk Kodek, Kec, Pemenang, Lombok Utara 83352, NTB, Indonesia,
   Indonesia.
EM dwilistyo@yahoo.com

TI Griffinia takedai, a new species of deep sea majoid crab (Decapoda,
   Brachyura, Epialtidae) from the Philippines.
AU Richer de Forges, Bertrand
   Ng, Peter K.L. (peterng@nus.edu.sg) 
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 275-284
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of deep-sea majoid is described from the eastern
   Philippines. Griffinia takedai n. sp. (Epialtidae) is the fourth species
   in this genus to be described, and it differs from congeners in its
   setose carapace, elongate rostral spines, as well as the well-developed
   supraorbital and hepatic spines. The new species is diagnosed, and a key
   to the genus is presented.

DT Article
TI A new species of Stegidotea Poore, 1985 (Isopoda, Chaetiliidae) from
   Japan.
AU Shimomura, Michitaka (shimomura@kmnh.jp) 
   Kakui, Keiichi
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 303-314
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Stegidotea takedai n. sp. is described from off Koshikijima Islands,
   Kyushu, western Japan, from a depth of 495-500 m. The new species
   differs from congeners in having a body about 2.2 times as long as wide;
   frontal margin of the head concave; sublateral projections of the pereon
   well-developed; articles 2 and 3 of the maxillipedal palp completely
   distinct; and the exopod of the uropod moderately short, being 0.7 times
   as long as endopod.

AN ZOOR14909039069
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Dulichiella (Amphipoda, Melitidae) from the
   Ogasawara Islands, Japan.
AU Tomikawa, Ko (tomikawa@hiroshima-u.ac.jp) 
   Komatsu, Hironori
SO Crustaceana Monographs
VL 17
PS 315-325
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new amphipod Dulichiella takedai sp. nov. is described from the
   Ogasawara Islands, Japan, only the second species of the genus from
   Japan. Dulichiella takedai is morphologically similar to D.
   appendiculata (Say, 1818) from the USA and D. cuvettensis Appadoo &
   Myers, 2005 from Mauritius, but D. takedai differs from D. appendiculata
   in having slender setae on urosomite 1 shorter than the spines, a
   developed fourth spine of the distolateral crown of larger male
   gnathopod 2 and the bases and meri of male pereopods 5-7 lacking bunches
   of long, slender setae. Dulichiella takedai differs from D. cuvettensis
   in having a minutely serrate posteroventral margin of epimeral plate 3,
   a short mandibular palp article 3 with more than eight slender setae,
   and equally developed third and fourth spines on the distolateral crown
   of larger male gnathopod 2.
C1 Tomikawa, Ko; Graduate School of Education, Hiroshima University, 1-1-1
   Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, Hiroshima 739-8524, Japan, Japan.
EM tomikawa@hiroshima-u.ac.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1570-7024
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Dulichiella takedai [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Amphipoda
OR Dulichiella takedai (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 316].

TI Notes on the systematics of East Asian Neozavrelia Goetghebuer (Diptera,
   Chironomidae, Tanytarsini).
AU Gilka, W. (scorpio@ocean.univ.gda.pl) 
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 11
IS 2
PS 35-39
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Diagnostic characters and the systematic position of selected Asian
   species of the genus Neozavrelia Goetghebuer, 1941 are discussed.
   Amended descriptions of Neozavrelia fengchengensis Wang et Wang, 1996
   and N. tamanona (Sasa, 1980) based of new records from North Korea are
   given. Five specific names published from Japan and originally ascribed
   to Cladotanytarsus Kieffer, 1921 are transferred to Neozavrelia as new
   combinations: N. simantolemea (Sasa, Suzuki et Sakai, 1998), N.
   simantomenea (Sasa, Suzuki et Sakai, 1998), N. tusimajekea (Sasa et
   Suzuki, 1999), N. yakuefea (Sasa et Suzuki, 2000) and N. yakufegea (Sasa
   et Suzuki, 2000).

TI Preliminary data on the chironomid fauna (Diptera, Chironomidae) of
   South Yakutia.
AU Makarchenko, E.A. (makarchenko@biosoil.ru) 
   Makarchenko, M.A.
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 11
IS 2
PS 67-84
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A preliminary annotated chironomid list of South Yakutia includes 67
   species of the subfamilies Podonominae (2), Diamesinae (1) and
   Orthocladiinae (64). Illustrated descriptions of four orthoclad species,
   Bryophaenocladius timptonensis sp.n., Eukiefferiella ternus sp.n.,
   Limnophyes chulmanensis sp.n. and Orthocladius (Mesorthocladius) ebrius
   sp.n., are new for science. For most species, taxonomic remarks and for
   all species type of distribution are adduced. A new version of a key for
   species identification of Orthocladius (Mesorthocladius) by pupa and
   larva of fourth instar is published.

PT J
AN ZOOR14909038599
DT Article
TI First Report of the Wild Tibetan Macaque (Macaca thibetana) as a New
   Primate Host of Gongylonema pulchrum with High Incidence in China.
AU Zhu, Yong
   Ji, Huan
   Li, Tin-Hua
   Xia, Dong-Po
   Sun, Bing-Hua
   Xu, Yu-Rui
   Kyes, Randall C.
SO Journal of Animal and Veterinary Advances
VL 11
IS 24
PS 4514-4518
PD 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The gullet worm, Gongylonema pulchrum Molin, 1857, a genus of nematodes
   belonging to the Superfamily Spiniroidea is a zoonosis that occurs in.
   the upper digestive tract of various mammals around the world. The hosts
   of this nematode are only reported in. few non-human Primates and
   infestation has not previously been reported in non-human Primates in
   China. Researchers collected 76 fresh fecal samples of Tibetan macaques
   during Nov. 2009 to Dec. 2009 and March 2010 to April 201 0 using
   washing precipitation and saturated saline flotation method for
   detection and identification of in. testinal parasites in macaques. The
   incidence of G. pulchrum infection was high to 31.58% which was the
   highest incidence rate among the 9 species intestinal parasites detected
   in Tibetan macaques. This research provides the first data concerning
   high incidence of G. pulchrum in wild Tibetan macaques in China which
   means enriched the host of the G. pulchrum in non-human Primates. The
   data would serve as a baseline for comparative assessments of disease
   risks, especially in. this well-known ecotourism site at Mt Huangshan,
   China.
C1 Zhu, Yong; Anhui Univ, Sch Resource & Environm Engn, Hefei, 230601,
   China, China.
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1680-5593; 1993-601X
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Gongylonema pulchrum [Mammalian hosts / Macaca thibetana / New record]
   [China /  / ]. 
   Macaca thibetana [Nematode parasites / Gongylonema pulchrum / New
   record] [China /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes; Primates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Primates, Cercopithecidae,
   Nematoda
OR Macaca thibetana (Cercopithecidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Gongylonema pulchrum (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14909038599
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14909038594

TI Ineffectiveness of a marine sanctuary zone to protect burrunan dolphins
   (Tursiops australis sp.nov.) from commercial tourism in Port Phillip
   Bay, Australia.
AU Howes, Leia (ljhowes@hotmail.com) 
   Scarpaci, Carol
   Parsons, Edward Christien M.
SO Journal of Ecotourism
VL 11
IS 3

PY 2012
LA English
U1 2
U2 10
AB Over the past two decades, considerable growth in commercial
   cetacean-based tourism has exposed coastal cetacean populations to high
   vessel density. Since 1989, Port Phillip Bay, Victoria, Australia, has
   hosted a thriving dolphin-swim tourism industry comprised of three
   licensed vessels. This study assessed the effectiveness of the
   Ticonderoga Bay Sanctuary Zone, a protected area enacted under the
   Wildlife (Whales) Regulations 1998, to serve the resident dolphins as an
   area of 'respite' and 'refuge' from anthropogenic stress, including
   commercial tourism. Research was conducted onboard 104 dolphin-swim
   tours, with both tour operation and dolphin school behaviour recorded
   using a combination of continuous observations and 1-min scan samples.
   During all observed encounters within the sanctuary zone, tour
   operations contravened the site-specific minimal approach distance
   regulation. By also contravening generic permit conditions (compliance
   range 0-70%) to the level of unsatisfactory compliance consistent with
   that documented outside the sanctuary zone, tour operations did not
   exercise any additional caution during a dolphin encounter within the
   sanctuary zone. Recommendations for this industry include a shift from
   sole reliance on passive management strategies to a judicious management
   plan that includes enforcement to support the governing regulations.
C1 Howes, Leia; Victoria Univ, Appl Ecol Res Grp, Melbourne, Vic, 8001,
   Australia, Australia.
